course.subject: COMP
course.name: Computer Vision
course.description: Introduction to techniques for automatically describing visual data and tools for image analysis; perception of spatial organization; models of general purpose vision systems; computational and psychological models of perception.

reviews.author: Pang.
reviews.comment_content:
Comprehensive course covering a multitude of computer vision topics. Heavily based on CMU 16-385. The list of topics can be grouped into the categories below:

- Image filters, feature extraction and matching
- Matching with cameras: homographies and stereo
- Radiometry, photometric stero, image processing (*)
- Traditional image classification: BoW, KNN, SVM etc.
- Introduction to NN and CNN
- Object tracking with optical flow
- Semantic segmentation (*)
- Visual SLAM (**)

* Not covered by assigments
** Not covered by assignments and exam

Previous knowledge in linear algebra is required.

This course only touches on the basics of neural networks-based computer vision. If you are looking for newer DL architectures / techniques then COMP5214 should be more suited for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Frankly speaking, Prof. Xu's delivery of the course materials are a bit bland and mostly involves reading from the slides. It does not help that the slides themselves are typically lengthy and not well organised.

Nevertheless, both Xu and the TA are very responsive towards emails and students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
My scores for reference:
HW (70%) 754/758
Final (30%) 75/90
Total 94.63% -> A

Prof. Xu did not release details on grade distribution other than guaranteeing half of the class get A- or above.

There are only 4 students who scored higher than me so I am *guessing* that absolute grading is used, with 95% being the threshold for A+. Roughly 60% of the class got >90% so that is likely the level needed to get A- or above.

In general the A-range is wide but A+ is only given to the top scorers. If that is your goal you may want to pay more attention to studying for the final exam (which I didn't) since a lot of people would be getting full scores on the assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is a total of 5 assignments, which weirdly enough are not arranged in ascending order:

PA2: Feature descriptors & homographies
PA4: 3D reconstruction
PA1: Spatial pyramid scene classification
PA5: Neural networks for
PA3: Object tracking with optical flow (Lucas-Kanade)

Project workload is very high. I spent a lot of time dealing with assignments even with prior experience in OpenCV and Pytorch.

The instructions for each assignment are quite convoluted; some tasks are to be implemented in code, some are theoretical questions which needs to be answered in a typed report, and some require both.

The good news is that there are (a lot of) project code on Github for one's reference, mostly by CMU students. You may want to check those if you got stuck doing the assignments. There are also a total of 10 grace days for late submission, without any score deduction. They helped a lot when I was coping with paper deadline during March.

In contrast, the final exam is relatively easier to prepare as it is fully open-notes and in MC questions only (though this may change when online courses revert to normal mode in the future). The only challenge lies within completing the exam under the limited time frame.

reviews.author: TryTryTry
reviews.comment_content: The complexity of this course material cannot be underestimated, including in-depth topics such as image transformation, Pose Estimation, Triangulation, reconstruction, reflectance, optical flow, and much more. Although mastering all of these topics may prove to be a challenge, it is not essential. Instead, focusing on understanding fundamental concepts and critical topics, such as SVD, the epipolar line, the essential matrix, and the optical flow equation, will suffice.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is really bad! I found it difficult to comprehend the professor's lectures due to his challenging accent and presentation style. Unfortunately, this led to me dropping a lot of classes. In order to make progress in the course, I resorted to self-teaching by reviewing the course materials and using online resources to supplement my learning.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good because around 40% students will get A- and above. The majority of the final grade is decided by the five projects, but the exam also carries significant weight. I am pleased to have earned an A+ for the course, which I attribute to the time I spent studying other universities' exam papers, a technique which proved to be very beneficial for the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is undeniably significant, with each project requiring a substantial amount of time to debug. As a PG student, I found it particularly challenging to spend an average of three days for each project. However, working through these projects ultimately helped me to develop a deeper understanding of the course content. I appreciated the support of the TAs, who were kind and only deducted points for blatantly incorrect results.

reviews.author: TrebledJ
reviews.title: Mediocre
reviews.comment_content:
Not much has changed so I won‚Äôt repeat. They still copy from Stanford and other schools. And I mean everything: assignments, exam questions, lectures topics.

But not bad overall, tries to balance between traditional CV approaches, theory, and modern ML/NN approaches.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures are pretty useless. In a typical lecture, you might encounter:

‚ÄúAnd you just apply the stupid Python, the stupid np.linalg.svd, and you get the stupid answer.‚Äù
‚ÄúLet me skip this boring math.‚Äù - proceeds to skip 20 slides.

Tbf, he does provide some decent analogies. But even with those, you‚Äôll probably gain more by self-studying.

It seems he has fun teaching and seeing us in class or during exams, but he doesn‚Äôt put the effort to deliver or prepare (or at least, I hope he puts more effort). Also no patience to curate the PowerPoint or go through the math?
reviews.comment_grading: No complaints. Fair overall. He likes to be generous.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments are quite tough and take time. The concept of late days is nice; I cashed in all of mine. üëç

Finals were in two parts: closed-book written answers, and open-book mcq.

Pretty chill for a UG, especially if you know where to look for resources.

reviews.author: Rookyii
reviews.comment_content: The content is theoretical but very useful. You can learn both classical CV and machine-learning-based CV.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is not too bad.
The prof. Xu Dan is very kind, while he is not so mature in teaching.
Anyway, he is very warm to students.
reviews.comment_grading: I have to say the grading is quite good. Only if you finish your HWs well, you may achieve B+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is somehow heavy. You have to write lots of code, but you have to admit that it is quite important to do this kind of dirty work.

reviews.author: pqd
reviews.comment_content: The content is very interesting. I learn a lot from this course. Most of the lectures are from CMU lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is not very interesting because Professor always reads the slides.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is acceptable. The Professor promises to give 50% of student A range. It is easy to get high score in the assignment parts. Also, the final exam is not very challenging because you can do it if you learn all the lectures.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite huge. Students have to finish many homework but you can learn a lot from it. The homework is in python language.

reviews.author: movingq
reviews.comment_content: The content itself is pretty good. You learn from the traditional CV to Deep Learning
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor speaks a bit fast. Quite hard to follow if you don't focus.
reviews.comment_grading: I have received good grade, but I am not too sure about others. I did just average on the assignments, but I did get a good result from the final exam. Final exam was (due to the covid-19) taken as online quiz, and it was pretty easy as it was just multiple choice questions.
reviews.comment_workload: The assignments are challenging, and you need to write code a lot.

reviews.author: kvoloshin
reviews.comment_content: Feels like a very complete overview of the computer vision field and builds from the ground up to more complicated topics. Definitely need a decent handle on programming (python) and a good understanding of linear algebra to follow along.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty engaging, does a good job of clearly explaining the material and addresses student questions.
reviews.comment_workload: You will have to put in a lot of work into the projects. Work will require a lot of coding and debugging. The projects themselves are pretty interesting and allow you to get some hands on experience with implementing the techniques covered in class.
